author: bmwlego
title: Minifig Included in a Promo!
review: This set is a cute little gliding vehicle and it actually includes a minifig. What a deal! There are quite a few specialty parts including panels, a propeller, tail, wheels, and antennae controls. The color scheme of black and yellow works nicely together and the alternate models pictured on the back of the bag are a small single seat plane, tiny watercraft and a mechanic working on a propeller. This is a great set that would have retailed for 2 bucks.

author: brixton
title: Too small
review: I got this set for free by ordering it from Kellogs years ago.  There isn't much to it.  Originally I thought the wings were great but had a change of heart when I got the Aerial Acrobats set which has much better plane wings.  The inclusion of a minifigure is great.  Without it there would be no point in picking this set up.  The Glory Glider set is just too small and simplistic.  I did not enjoy it as a kid.

author: stitchfan
title: The first one is always free...
review:
Possibly the best Kellogg's promotions ever, Sets 1560, 1561, 1562, and 1563 were the sets I remember most vividly as a kid. Probably because my thrifty mom earned me about 3 of each through this Promo. I still have the unmistakable parts floating through around Lego my bins after all these years, and they're still as useful.

Pros

  • Free Lego sets!
  • Simple sets, good parts
  • Great for beginners just starting with Lego
  • Good for play time, since they come with mini figures and moving parts

Cons


  • Not many parts to work with, leaving limited re-build options as stand-alone sets
  • Simplicity and few parts might leave the experienced Lego builder uninterested

Let's just hope Kellogg's (or someone) has a deal this good again in the future!
